Polystyrene supported Zinc complex as an efficient catalyst for cyclic carbonate formation via CO2 fixation under atmospheric pressure and organic carbamates production Surajit Biswas a Resmin Khatun a Manideepa Sengupta a b Sk. Manirul Islam a ⁎ a Department of Chemistry, University of Kalyani, Kalyani, Nadia, 741235, West Bengal, India Department of Chemistry University of Kalyani Nadia Kalyani West Bengal 741235 India b Refinery Technology Division, CSIR-Indian Institute of Petroleum, Dehradun, 248005, Uttarakhand, India Refinery Technology Division CSIR-Indian Institute of Petroleum Dehradun Uttarakhand 248005 India ⁎ Corresponding author at: Department of Chemistry, University of Kalyani, Kalyani, Nadia, 741235, West Bengal, India. Department of Chemistry University of Kalyani Nadia Kalyani West Bengal 741235 India Graphical abstract A heterogeneous, [PS-Zn(II)L] catalyst, has been synthesized from organically modified chloromethylated polystyrene and characterized by IR, AAS, TG-DTA, SEM and EDX studies. [PS-Zn(II)L] catalyst showed its efficient catalytic activity towards the formation of cyclic carbonate from epoxides via CO2 fixation at room temperature under 1 atm CO2 pressure and production of organic carbamates from corresponding amines. Chemical fixation of CO2 and synthesis of organic carbamates through phosgene –free eco-friendly pathway using a heterogeneous and sustainable catalyst is always a demanding field in synthesis chemistry. Herein, we presented the design and synthesis of a polymer support sustainable heterogeneous [PS-Zn(II)L] catalyst from modified chloromethylated polystyrene. The heterogeneous catalyst has been characterized by IR, PXRD, AAS, TG-DTA, SEM and EDX studies. The catalyst showed its efficient catalytic activity towards the formation of organic cyclic carbonate from epoxides via CO2 fixation at room temperature under 1 atm CO2 pressure in solvent free condition and production of organic carbamates from corresponding amines. The synthesis of carbamates in presence of this catalyst is a phosgene-free protocol where green reagent Dimethyl carbonate (DMC) is used as a carboxylating agent as well as the solvent. The catalyst is highly efficient and reusable even after five cycles. Keywords Polystyrene support Heterogeneous catalyst CO2 fixation Cyclic carbonate Organic carbamates 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide (CO2) which is generated from human activities is one of the greenhouse gases. Thus its atmospheric concentration should be controlled by eliminating it from industrial emissions to avoid global warming which is the most dangerous environmental threat in recent years [1]. On the other side, CO2 is a cheap and abundant recyclable carbon source. It is a very powerful, non-flammable, non-toxic C1 feedstock for organic synthesis and can sometimes replace toxic chemicals like carbon monoxide, isocyanates or phosgene [2]. It has been found that CO2 utilization is more significant rather than its storage if economical procedures are accessible. That’s why chemical fixation of CO2 into value-added chemicals is still gaining appreciable attention. The cyclo addition of CO2 to epoxides for the formation of cyclic organic carbonates is one of the very useful chemical transformations of CO2. The cyclic carbonates have a wide range of applications as aprotic polar solvents, in polycarbonate precursors like Diphenyl carbonate (DPC), and Dimethyl carbonate (DMC), electrolytes in rechargeable batteries and intermediates in synthesis of fine chemicals [3]. In the conventional method, the cyclic carbonates were synthesized via a poisonous, hazardous, and corrosive route involving glycol and phosgene. Now a days these cyclic carbonates are produced through the cyclo addition of CO2 to epoxides in presence of catalysts. There are many homogeneous catalysts already been developed for this catalytic transformation like quaternary phosphonium/ammonium salts [4], ionic liquids [5], alkali metal salts [6], bromine [7], organo catalyst [8], metal complexes [9], peroxometalates [10] etc. But these homogeneous catalysts have the most common problems of recyclability and reusability. Alternatively, many heterogeneous catalytic systems have been also developed to overcome these problems e.g., inorganic-organic hybrid core shell microspheres [11], COFs, [12] MOFs [13] etc. But most of the catalytic system require harsh reaction conditions such as hazardous organic solvent, very high CO2 pressure and temperature. For these aspects, it is very much desirable to explore recyclable and reusable catalytic system, which can perform its catalytic activity under atmospheric pressure, room temperature and solvent free condition. That’s why; we have been designed and synthesized a polymer supported zinc metal complex which can act as an efficient heterogeneous catalyst for the synthesis of cyclic carbonate under 1 atm CO2 pressure and room temperature in solvent free condition. Organic carbamates are the very popular class of compounds which grasp inimitable applications in agrochemicals (as insecticides, herbicides, pesticides, fungicides etc.) [14] and pharmaceuticals (in form of drugs and pro-drugs) [15]. Moreover, the carbamates play a pivotal role against various diseases, like anti-viral, anti-malarial, anti-HIV, anti-cancer, anti-progestational, anti-fungal, anti-estrogenic, anti-bacterial, anti-tubercular, anti-osteoporosis, anti-diabetic, anti-inflammatory, anti-obesity, anti-filarial, anti-helminths, anti-convulsant, anti-Alzheimer drugs and CVS, CNS active agents [15a,f,16]. The compounds are very competent in the peptide chemistry for the protection of amino group [17], in the organic synthesis as intermediate [18] and in the combinatorial chemistry as linker [19]. The carbamates have also been widely utilized in the synthesis of molecules of biological significance and structurally diverse synthetic intermediates [20]. These compounds are generally manufactured from the reaction of corresponding amine and phosgene or phosgene derivatives [21]. But the process is not environmentally friendly and produced toxic and unwanted waste materials. For that reason, some greener protocols for the synthesis of these compounds have been developed in recent years such as catalytic oxidative carbonylation of amines [22], carbonylation of nitroaromatics [23], methoxy carbonylation through carbonate [24], and by reaction of urea with symmetrical carbonates [25]. The carbonylation process involves the toxic CO and the latest process of urea and carbonates has bound to access the limited number of carbamates derivatives [25]. Therefore, probably the most attractive route for the synthesis of organic carbamates is the methoxy carboxylation of amine using dimethyl carbonate (DMC) in presence of a catalyst. In green chemistry, DMC is a very versatile building block for organic synthesis and produced carbamates from amine in the one-step process. For this purpose, a number of catalysts have been developed for the synthesis of carbamates from dialkyl carbonates and amines including phosphoric acid [26], lead salts [27], MCM-41-TBD [28], Yb(OTf)3 [29], Zn salt containing catalysts [30], ZrO2/SiO2 [31], Zn(OAc)2-[bmim]PF6 [32], acid functional ionic liquids [33], IL-Co Catalyst [34]. But most of the above mention catalysts are homogeneous in nature as a result reusability and recyclability of those catalysts are very problematic and also very cost effective. Moreover, the catalysis procedure required the temperature greater than 100 °C and long reaction duration. Hence, design and synthesis of heterogeneous catalyst are essential for the efficient production of organic carbamates from amine and DMC under mild condition. Herein, we are able to synthesize a polymer-supported Zinc catalyst which is very efficient for the synthesis of organic carbamates from amine and DMC under mild condition. In this paper, we have reported the synthesis, characterization of an organically modified polystyrene supported Zinc catalyst and its efficient dual catalytic activity towards the synthesis of cyclic carbonate at room temperature under 1 atm CO2 pressure and solvent-free condition as well as the production of organic carbamates under mild condition from corresponding amine and DMC. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Chloromethylated polystyrene and epoxides were procured from Sigma-Aldrich. Amines were purchased from Merck (India). The reagents were used as received without any purification and solvents were distilled and dried through standard procedure prior to use. 2.2 Characterization techniques The elemental analysis was carried out on Exeter Analytical Inc. model: CE 440. FTIR spectra were done on a Perkin-Elmer FTIR 783 spectrophotometer using KBr pellets. Mettler Toledo TGA/DTA 851 instrument was used for Thermogravimetric (TGA) analysis. The morphology of samples was measured using a scanning electron microscope (SEM) (ZEISS EVO40, England) equipped with EDAX facility. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AMX- 400 instrument using tetramethylsilane as internal standard. AAS analysis for the measurement of zinc metal loading on polymer support was determined on Spectra- AA 240 (Agilent Technologies). The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were taken on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer using Cu-K α radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) operating at 40 kV and 40 mA. The XRD patterns were recorded in the 2θ range of 3–50 using a LynxEye detector (1D mode) with a step size of 0.02 and a dwell time of 1 s per step. 2.3 Preparation of the catalyst Schematic presentation for the preparation of the polystyrene-supported Zinc metal catalyst ([PS-Zn(II)L]) is shown in Scheme 1 . 2.3.1 Preparation of polystyrene supported schiff base ligand [PS-H2L] Polymer-supported Schiff base ligand [PS-H2L] was synthesized by two steps synthetic procedure. In the first step, salicylaldehyde (30 mmol) and diethylenetriamine (15 mmol) were taken in 20 ml ethanol in a 50 ml round-bottom flask. The mixture was heated to reflux for 24 h. Then the reaction mixture was cooled at room temperature and the solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure to yield a concentrated orange liquid product. The Schiff base ligand H2L was then dried under vacuum. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 2.882 (s, 4H), 3.672 (s, 4H), 5.112 (s, −NH), 6.730-7.210 (m, 8H, aromatic), 8.230 (s, 2-OH) ppm (Fig. S1). In the next step, polymer supported Schiff base ligand [PS-H2L] was prepared by taking 1gm of Merrifield resin and H2L (3.11gm, 10 mmol) in 20 ml tetrahydrofuran and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 48 h. The obtained light yellow solid product was filtered, washed with de-ionized H2O followed by ethanol and dried under vacuum. 2.3.2 Preparation of [PS-Zn(II)L] catalyst 1gm of polystyrene supported Schiff base ligand [PS-H2L] was dispersed in 20 ml ethanol in a 50 ml round-bottom flask. Then 5 ml of 1% (W/V) zinc chloride solution was added drop wise to the former mixture under the stirring condition and the whole mixture was refluxed under the same condition for 12 h. The mixture was cooled to room temperature and the obtained solid product was filtered, washed with ethanol and dried under vacuum. 2.3.3 General procedure of cyclic carbonate synthesis from epoxide under 1 atmospheric CO2 pressure Epoxides (5 mmol), [PS-Zn(II)L] catalyst (50 mg, 0.028 mmol based on Zn metal) and Bu4NBr (26.7 mg, 0.083 mmol) were taken in a 25 ml round-bottom flask which is fitted with a cork of rubber penetrated with a balloon of CO2 and a magnetic stirrer bar. Then the solution was stirred vigorously at room temperature for the required time to complete the reaction (monitored by TLC). The conversions of the reactions were determined by Gas Chromatography (GC) and isolated cyclic carbonates were identified by 1H NMR spectroscopy. 2.3.4 General procedure for the synthesis of organic carbamates To a 25 ml round-bottom flask 5 mmol of amine and 50 mg (0.028 mmol based on Zn metal) of catalyst were added to 25 mmol of DMC. The reaction mixture was stirred at 60 °C under the nitrogen atmosphere for the required time to complete the reaction (monitored by TLC). Then the mixture was cooled to room temperature and separates the catalyst through filtration. The excess DMC and byproduct MeOH were recovered by distillation. Then to the obtained reaction mixture, 10 ml water was added, the desired product was precipitated out. The product was collected by filtration, washing, and dryness. The recovered catalyst was reused for recycling test. The conversion of the reaction was determined by GC and isolated pure products were characterized by IR and 1H NMR spectroscopy. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of [PS-Zn(II)L]catalyst 3.1.1 Elemental analysis The elemental analysis data of polystyrene supported ligand and catalyst are given in Table 1 . The loading of zinc metal on the organically modified support was determined by AAS spectroscopy. The weight percentage of chlorine in the ligand and the catalyst suggested by elemental analysis are 1.18% and 2.94% respectively. So, the percentage of chlorine coordinated to Zn metal is 1.76%. Now the calculated mole ratio of Cl/Zn is 0.87 which is nearly equal to 1; the ideal Cl/Zn molar ratio of the complex. The mole ratio of N/Zn is 3.11 which is also equal to the ideal value of mole ratio of N/Zn (i.e. 3) of the complex. Again that of O/Zn is 2.03. Therefore, all these data are in good agreement with the expected structure of [PS-Zn(II)L] catalyst as shown in Scheme 1. 3.1.2 FT-IR spectroscopy Chloromethylated polystyrene shows a strong IR active band at 1263 cm−1 due to ν(CCl). This band is not observed in IR spectrum of [PS-H2L] which confirms the attachment of Schiff base H2L to the polymer support. IR spectrum of [PS-H2L] also exhibits a broadband at the range 3050–3500 cm−1 due to ν(OH) and sharp bands at 1622 cm−1due to ν(CN). The disappearance of the broad band (3050–3500 cm−1) in [PS-Zn(II)L] catalyst indicates the coordination of phenolic −OH to Zn metal (Fig. 1 ). The shifting of ν(CN) band from 1622 cm−1 to 1615 cm−1 further assure the complexation of [PS-H2L] ligand to Zn metal through azomethine nitrogen. 3.1.3 Power X-ray diffraction analysis Both [PS-H2L] ligand and [PS-Zn(II)L] catalyst exhibit a broadband at the range of 2θ (10–30) which clearly confirms the amorphous nature of ligand as well as the catalyst [35]. Thus, there was no nano-crystalline material of ZnO is formed after the introduction of metal onto the ligand (Fig. 2 ). 3.1.4 Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images and energy dispersive X-Ray (EDX) analysis The SEM images of [PS-H2L] ligand (a) and [PS-Zn(II)L] catalyst (b) are shown in Fig. 3 . A clear change observed in the morphological pattern of the [PS-H2L] ligand after incorporation of Zn metal. [PS-H2L] ligand showed sheet-like morphology of average size (∼2 μm) whereas in catalyst fungal-like zinc complex deposited on the sheet. EDX analysis of ligand and catalyst further support the presence of Zn metal on organically modified polymer support (Fig. 4 ). 3.1.5 Thermal analysis To determine the stability of modified polymer support ligand and catalyst thermo-gravimetric analysis were carried out under the nitrogen atmosphere with heating rate 10 °C min−1 in between temperature range from 30 to 600 °C. The PS-H2L ligand is stable up to 150 °C; beyond that temperature, decomposition occurs (Fig. 5 ). Whereas the [PS-Zn(II)L] catalyst is thermally more stable than the ligand. In [PS-Zn(II)L] catalyst two-step decomposition occurs, one weight loss is in between the temperature range of 250–450 °C due to salen group of catalyst starts to decompose [36] and other is beyond 450 °C due to final decomposition of the catalyst. 3.2 Catalytic activity 3.2.1 Catalytic formation of cyclic carbonate from epoxides under 1 atm CO2 pressure The catalytic activity of synthesized [PS-Zn(II)L] catalyst was tested in the formation of cyclic carbonates from epoxides through CO2 fixation reaction. Use of harmful CO2 for the formation of cyclic carbonate from the corresponding epoxides is the very important reaction of CO2 fixation into value-added products (Scheme 2 ). To optimize the reaction conditions, we vary the amount of catalyst, Bu4NBr and the reaction duration by taking epichlorohydrine carbonate formation from epichlorohydrine as a model reaction (Table 2 , entries 1–10). When the reaction is carried out in presence of our catalyst (50 mg) without Bu4NBr, 40% conversion of the substrate occurs after 8 h in room temperature under 1 atm CO2 pressure (Table 2, entries 10) whereas in presence of 4 mol% of Bu4NBr without catalyst only 24% conversion (Table 2, entries 2) take place under the same reaction condition. We got the best result when the reaction is performed in presence of 5 mol% of Bu4NBr and 50 mg (0.028 mmol based on Zn metal) of the catalyst at room temperature in 8 h under 1 atm of CO2 pressure (Table 2, entries 9). Different cyclic carbonates of corresponding epoxides were synthesized through CO2 fixation under this optimized reaction condition. Various substrates of epoxides, like styrene oxide, epichlorohydrin, allyl glycidyl ether, cyclohexene oxide, propylene oxide, and 1, 2-epoxy-3-phenoxy propane, glycidyl isopropyl ether etc. formed cyclic carbonate derivatives via CO2 fixation reaction. Most of the substrates undergo efficient transformation to five-member organic cyclic carbonates with high conversion and selectivity (Table 3 , entries 1–7). It was observed that both electron-withdrawing and electron-donating groups of terminal epoxides could easily be converted to carbonates with more or less quantitative yields in 8 h at room temperature under 1 atm of CO2 pressure. Table 4 is showing the comparison of the catalytic activity of our catalyst with other reported catalytic systems for the synthesis of styrene carbonate. Zn(salphen) complex catalyst [37] gave only 66% yield of styrene carbonate at 25 °C under 1 MPa CO2 pressure in DCM medium after 18 h whereas other catalysts [38–40,9b] produced (75–88%) of styrene carbonate at the higher temperature (120 °C) and CO2 pressure (∼2 MPa). A nanocrystal Mesoporous Zn-Sn (ZSM) [41] catalyst produced 95% of carbonate at 80 °C under 0.1 MPa (1 atm) CO2 pressure in PEG-600 solvent. On the other side HPFP-1(NP) nanomaterial catalyst showed 97% carbonate yield at room temperature, 1 atm CO2 pressure under solvent free medium in 12 h. In case of our catalyst which gave comparable yield (98%) of carbonate under same reaction condition but in lower reaction duration (8 h). 3.2.2 Reaction mechanism In the previously reported paper of catalytic conversion of epoxides to cyclic carbonate by a bimetallic [Al(III)salen] complex in presence of Bu4NBr, the mechanism of the catalytic reaction was examined and established properly [50]. The breakdown of Bu4NBr and the development of amine carbamate salts are also well accepted in the literature [43,44]. Although we could not separate any intermediate species, we mention a probable mechanism in Scheme 3 based on previous reports. The catalytic cycle begins with activation of the epoxide by the Lewis acidic Zn centre of [PS-Zn(II)L], then nucleophilic attack of the bromine ion caused the ring-opening to make the metal-bonded bromo-alkoxide. After that, so formed alkoxide species acts as the nucleophile and attacks CO2 to form the metal carbonate species, which then produced the cyclic carbonate through an intramolecular ring-closure reaction and make the catalyst-free. 3.2.3 Catalytic synthesis of organic carbamates from amine and DMC The catalytic activity of [PS-Zn(II)L] catalyst was also tested in the formation of organic carbamates from aromatic amine using DMC. In absence of the catalyst, the reaction of aniline and DMC did not yield any desired product after a long time of reaction. The effect of temperature and amount of catalyst were monitored to optimize the catalytic conditions of the reaction. The conversion of reaction between aniline and DMC at room temperature was 40% with desired product selectivity 55% after 12 h (Table 5 , Entry 4) with increased the temperature to 60 °C, the conversion became 100% with >99% selectivity after 2 h (Table 5, Entry 6). Based on the above experiments, the optimized reaction conditions for the catalytic synthesis of carbamates should be amine (1 equivalent) and DMC (5 equivalent) in 50 mg (0.028 mmol based on Zn metal) of the catalyst at 60 °C with absent of other organic solvents. Use of excess DMC has been active as a carboxylating agent as well as the solvent of the reaction medium. Under this optimized protocol we synthesized various organic carbamates from different aromatic amines. The results are summarized in Table 6 . From comparison table (Table 7 ), it is clear that the catalyst [PS-Zn(II)L] is very efficient for the synthesis of organic carbamates under mild condition within a short reaction time (2 h). Table 7 represents the comparison of the catalytic efficiency of our catalyst with other reported catalysts for the formation of carbamates of aniline. Most of the reported catalytic systems showed a good conversion (>80%) of aniline with high product selectivity at temperature ≥ 130 °C. Only IL-Co catalyst produced 90% isolated yield of carbamates at mild temperature 60 °C [45] whereas 97% isolated product of aniline carbamate is produced by our catalyst at the same temperature (60 °C). 3.3 Heterogeneity of catalyst [PS-Zn(II)L] Zinc metal was not leached from catalyst [PS-Zn(II)L] during the course of the catalytic reaction. This observation was confirmed by IR, AAS analysis of the fresh and used catalyst. The similarity of IR spectrums of the reused and fresh catalyst assured that Zn metal was intact in catalyst surface after the reaction. AAS analysis of both fresh and used catalyst (Table 1) indicates that the metal loading remains almost same before and after the catalysis. AAS analysis was also carried out for the product mixtures of reaction between epichlorohydrin and CO2 which did not show the presence of Zn metal in the mixture. This data also supports that Zn was not leaching from catalyst throughout the catalytic reaction. All the above observations definitely assert the nature of heterogeneity of [PS-Zn(II)L] catalyst. 3.4 Recycling of catalyst It is the prime feature to investigate the separation, recoverability and reusability of a heterogeneous catalyst. The catalytic recyclability was examined in the formation of cyclic carbonate for the model reaction between epichlorohydrin and CO2 and also in the synthesis of organic carbamate from aniline and DMC. After each catalytic cycle, the catalyst was separated by filtration and washed thoroughly with distilled water followed by ether. Then it was dried in an oven at 90 °C for 12 h. From Fig. 6 , we can conclude that the catalyst is very efficient even after use of five cycles. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, a heterogeneous catalyst, [PS-Zn(II)L] is designed and synthesized from organically modified chloromethylated polystyrene. The catalyst was characterized by IR, PXRD, AAS, SEM, EDX and thermogravimetric analysis. It is the very efficient catalyst for the fixation of CO2 in epoxides to corresponding cyclic carbonates as well as the synthesis of organic carbamates from amines and DMC. Here, the reported process of the synthesis of cyclic carbonate is hazardless, cost-effective and environment-friendly which performs at room temperature under 1 atm of CO2 pressure in a solvent-free condition. The use of green reagent DMC for the preparation of carbamates is the phosgene-free non-hazardous process and occurs under mild reaction conditions. The catalyst is very stable, even after five catalytic cycles it conserved its catalytic efficacy. coredata.dc:description: Chemical fixation of CO2 and synthesis of organic carbamates through phosgene –free eco-friendly pathway using a heterogeneous and sustainable catalyst is always a demanding field in synthesis chemistry. Herein, we presented the design and synthesis of a polymer support sustainable heterogeneous [PS-Zn(II)L] catalyst from modified chloromethylated polystyrene. The heterogeneous catalyst has been characterized by IR, PXRD, AAS, TG-DTA, SEM and EDX studies. The catalyst showed its efficient catalytic activity towards the formation of organic cyclic carbonate from epoxides via CO2 fixation at room temperature under 1 atm CO2 pressure in solvent free condition and production of organic carbamates from corresponding amines. The synthesis of carbamates in presence of this catalyst is a phosgene-free protocol where green reagent Dimethyl carbonate (DMC) is used as a carboxylating agent as well as the solvent. The catalyst is highly efficient and reusable even after five cycles.
coredata.dc:title: Polystyrene supported Zinc complex as an efficient catalyst for cyclic carbonate formation via CO2 fixation under atmospheric pressure and organic carbamates production
